dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Chaudhry, S. 2010. Badis blosyrus. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description: Badis blosyrus is found in the lower reaches of Brahmaputra in Assam and Nagaland (Vishwanath pers. comm.), and a species tentatively identified from Buxa Tiger Reserve, West Bengal, India. Collected only once by the German Expedition in 1957. It may be present in Bhutan.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology
dataObjects.description: Dorsal spines (total): 16 - 17; Dorsal soft rays (total): 8 - 11; Analsoft rays: 7 - 8; Vertebrae: 27 - 29

dataObjects.title: Max. size
dataObjects.references: Kullander, S.O. and R. Britz 2002 Revision of the family Badidae (Teleostei: Perciformes), with description of a new genus and ten new species. Ichthyol. Explor. Freshwat. 13(4):295-372. (Ref. 46238)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObjects.description: Possesses a prominent dark blotch posterodorsally on opercle and two rows of irregular blackish blotches along side.  Differs from B. assamensis by longer jaw, upper jaw 12-13.6 SL); lower jaw 16.3-18.5%SL, having fewer scales in lateral row, more gill rakers, and fewer vertebrae (Ref. 46238).

dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Chaudhry, S. 2010. Badis blosyrus. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description:
Red List Category
LC
Least Concern

Red List Criteria

Version
3.1

Year Assessed
2010

Assessor/s
Chaudhry, S.

Reviewer/s
Jha, B.R., Allen, D.J., Datta, N.C., Britz, R., Dey, S.C. & Vishwanath, W.

Contributor/s
Molur, S.

Justification
Badis blosyrus is known from only few localities of Assam, Nagaland, in India, and may be present in West Bengal. Presence in Bhutan may be inferred. More research is needed to validate the population and distribution of this species. It is assessed as Least Concern, but this should be revised if further information confirming a more restricted distribution arrises.
